The Batman: A Gritty Take on the Caped Crusaderâ€™s Story

By Kyle Boulton

Michael Athey looks at Pattinsonâ€™s performance and the dark aesthetic of the new Batman film

Review: The Northman

By Kyle Boulton

Sophia Ash excavates the bloody core of Robert Eggers' unrelenting blockbuster

True Grit

<em>True Grit</em> has confirmed the Coen brothers as leading 21st century filmmakers. Just as last year's <em>Shutter Island</em> was the biggest ever hit of an acclaimed director like Martin Scorsese, the pair normally associated with a non-conformist quirkiness have had their greatest box office success to date

'It's About Time The Oscars Stopped Being So Political'

Gareth Davies speaks to Brian Timoney, the UK's leading method acting coach about the politics of the Oscars and the race for 'Best Actor' (Thumbnail credit Javier Bardem in Biutiful)

Gnomeo and Juliet (3D)

If you like bastardised re-tellings of classic Shakespeare stories which use the under-rated medium of garden ornaments to deliver kitschy, watered-down rom-com stuff, then this is clearly the film for you

Rabbit Hole

Based on the Pulitzer-winning play of the same name by David Lindsay-Abaire, <em>Rabbit Hole</em> offers us a concentrated and epiphanic insight into the lives of grieving parents, Becca (Nicole Kidman) and Howie (Aaron Eckhart)

Brighton Rock

This month has seen the release of the much anticipated remake of the Graham Greene novel adaptation, <em>Brighton Rock</em>. Greene's tale of violence and love in late 1930s Brighton is here retold in a swinging sixties setting, showcasing such British talent as Helen Mirren, John Hurt and Andy Serkis. What could possibly go wrong?

BAFTA: 2011's Winners

Following its success at the Golden Globes <em>The King's Speech</em> emerges from this year's BAFTA ceremony with a royal flush

The BAFTAs 2011 - Live

The BAFTAs are fast-approaching, and the stars are now milling around London Opera House where Jonathan Ross will soon be kicking off this year's awards ceremony

A Little Bit of Heaven

In Nicole Kassell's film <em>A Little Bit of Heaven</em>, Kate Hudson plays Marley, a boho-chic ad-exec who is respectable yet free, a beloved friend with a bit of a foul mouth

What didn't make the Oscars' shortlist?

Last year, it came as something of a surprise when breakout sci-fi hit <em>District 9</em> was nominated for Best Picture at the Oscars (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: C.A.P. via Flickr Creative Commons)

The Rising Stars of 2010/11

BAFTA's rising star award is voted for by the public. Michael Allard looks at the nominees

I'll Take You To Babylon

Mohamed Al-Daradji, Middle Eastern Film-maker of the Year speaks to Gareth Davies about his new movie <em>Son of Babylon</em> and <em>Iraq's Missing Campaign</em>

This is what dreams are made of

Film Noir is back. Adrian Choa explores the evolution of the elusive form

Top 5 Boxing Movies

To celebrate the release of <em>The Fighter</em>, we look at the five greatest boxing movies ever made

The Fighter

One wishes that there could be something to riff on about <em>The Fighter</em> - some crucial flaw that undercuts the otherwise brilliant nature of the film, that could be exploited mercilessly for both comic effect and to subvert the glowing tone of other reviewers. But here's the thing: this is easily the best sports movie of the last ten years

Never Let Me Go

<em>Never Let Me Go</em>, based on Kazuo Ishiguro's novel of the same name, is a movie which, despite its bio-ethical and medical concerns manages to cast off any traditional science fiction imagery, finding itself closer to home as a period drama of sorts

How Do You Know

Romantic comedies have inevitably become something of a staple in modern cinema

Tangled

Disney's newest film, <em>Tangled</em>, takes the classic story of Rapunzel and manages to make it suitable for a twenty-first century audience

Hereafter

With <em>Hereafter</em>, Clint Eastwood joins Ron Howard, Peter Weir, Paul Haggis and Edward Zwick as a multiple-Academy Award winner or nominee whose latest film is not really a part of the awards circus this year, despite having an awards season release date

The Dilemma

Ron Howard's latest film is premised on what is essentially schoolboy banter: whether or not a guy (Vince Vaughn) ought to tell another guy (Kevin James) that his wife is cheating on him

Morning Glory

<em>Morning Glory</em> is the sort of film that takes a compelling stand in favour of trashy television, in this case, the typical American Breakfast show

Blue Valentine

As with other bygone romantic dramas, <em>Blue Valentine</em> is set in two different time frames

The Green Hornet

It could have been fantastic. Based on the radio series of the same name - a smooth if madcap extended serial that bears little resemblance to its visual counterpart - <em>The Green Hornet</em> had all the ingredients to reinvent the superhero genre

Cinema is dead. Long live cinema!

The rise of 3D: Adrian Choa explores its implications for the future of film

Top 5 Ballet Movies

To celebrate the release of <em>Black Swan</em>, we look at the five greatest ballet movies

127 Hours

It's becoming clear that Danny Boyle is a man who relishes a challenge. This was none more apparent than in 2008 with <em>Slumdog Millionaire</em>, a movie shot largely on location in India with a host of local actors and a chaotic filming schedule

Black Swan

<em>Black Swan</em> sees Natalie Portman make a career defining performance as Nina, a twenty-something ballerina who pushes her body to its limits for the lead role in her company's production of Swan Lake

Black Swan Competition

Darren Aronofsky's <em>Black Swan</em>, released on the 21st January, is set to be one of this year's hottest releases. Starring Natalie Portman as a mentally fragile ballerina, who credited with the lead role in her company's production of Swan Lake, finds herself on a dark, sexual and exhilarating downward spiral

The Next Three Days

Some movie stars do their best acting when they escape from the blockbusters they're normally drawn to

The King's Speech

"Contains strong language in a speech therapy context." A warning that was added after the makers of <em>The King's Speech</em> successfully lobbied to have the film's rating taken down from a 15 to a 12A, it must be one of the funniest caveats ever attached to a movie by the British Board of Film Classification

Amer

Out of the depths of the French underground comes this bizarre and visceral meditation on sexual desire.

True Grit

<em>True Grit</em> has confirmed the Coen brothers as leading 21st century filmmakers. Just as last year's <em>Shutter Island</em> was the biggest ever hit of an acclaimed director like Martin Scorsese, the pair normally associated with a non-conformist quirkiness have had their greatest box office success to date

Brighton Rock

This month has seen the release of the much anticipated remake of the Graham Greene novel adaptation, <em>Brighton Rock</em>.
